7.1.p1.ga: Úsáidtear an chopail chun dhá fhocal nó dhá abairtín a cheangal le chéile.
7.1.p1.en: The copula is used to associate two words or phrases together.

7.1.p2.ga: Is ionann an leagan den chopail a úsáidtear san aimsir láithreach agus an leagan a úsáidtear san aimsir fháistineach. Ina theannta sin, is ionann an leagan den chopail a úsáidtear san aimsir chaite agus an leagan a úsáidtear san aimsir ghnáthchaite agus sa mhodh coinníollach. Tabhair faoi deara, más san aimsir chaite, san aimsir ghnáthchaite nó sa mhodh coinníollach atá faisnéis na habairte, nach gá go mbeadh aimsir na copaile agus aimsir fhaisnéis na habairte ag aontú le chéile. Féach 7.2 le haghaidh fhoirmeacha simplí na copaile.
7.1.p2.en: The layout of the copula used in the present tense is the same as that used in the future tense. Moreover, the layout of the copula, when used in the past tense, the past habitual, and the conditional mood, is the same. Bear in mind, if the predicate of the sentence is in the past tense, the present tense, or  the conditional mood, the tense of the copula and the tense of the predicate would not necessarily agree with each other. See 7.2 for simple forms of the copula. ``[This paragraph needs to be rephrased to make it clearer. -dcw]``

7.1.1.p2.en: The primary functions of the copula are—

7.1.1.b.samples: ``Is`` é Baile Átha Cliath príomhchathair na hÉireann.
Dublin is the capital of Ireland.

7.1.1.c.ga: an t-ainmní a cháiliú le faisnéis aidiachtach nó le frása a thosaíonn ar réamhfhocal:
7.1.1.c.en: qualification of the subject with a predicate adjective or with a phrase starting with a preposition:

7.1.1.d.ga: ainmfhocal nó clásal a cháiliú le haidiacht, nó le hainmfhocal, móide forainmneach réamhfhoclach:
7.1.1.d.en: qualification of a noun or clause, or with a noun plus a prepositional pronoun:

7.1.1.d.samples: We are sorry for this break. (?)

7.1.1.e.ga: ainmfhocal a cháiliú le breischéim aidiachta:
7.1.1.e.en: qualification of a noun with a comparative adjective:

7.1.1.e.samples: Tabhair leat an ceann ``is`` fearr leat.
Bhí na milseáin ``ba`` dheise ite sular shroich mé an chóisir.
The nicest sweets were eaten before I arrived at the party.

7.1.1.f.ga: úinéireacht nó gaol idir daoine a chur in iúl trína húsáid leis an réamhfhocal `le`:
7.1.1.f.en: expression of ownership or relationship between people using the preposition `le`:

7.1.1.g.en: qualification of a clause with an adjective:

7.1.1.g.samples: ``Is`` gearr go mbeidh a fhios againn.
It has been a long time since he was there.
``Is`` iomaí duine a thagann an treo seo.
He was a long time coming.

7.1.1.h.ga: béim a leagan ar chuid den abairt:

7.1.1.h.samples: ``Ní`` inniu ná inné a saolaíodh eisean.
He was not born today or yesterday.
``Is`` ag ceannach bainne a bhí mé.
``Is`` chun na Spáinne a chuaigh sí.
It was to Spain she went.
``Ní`` hí Muireann a chaill an eochair.
It was not Muireann that lost the key.
``Ba`` í Nóra a d'aistrigh é sin.
``Níorbh`` é sin an cineál comórtais a bhí ann in 1998.
That was not the kind of competition that was there in 1998.
``Is`` é Peadar a dhéanfadh an beart dá mbeadh sé anseo.
Peadar would make the move if he were here.

7.1.1.i.ga: í a úsáid in abairtí a chuireann comparáid in iúl:
7.1.1.i.en: using it in sentences that express a comparison:

7.1.1.i.samples: ``Is`` troime bonn dhá phingin ná bonn pingine.
A twopence is heavier than a penny.
``Is`` gile an ghrian ná an ghealach agus ná na pláinéid.
The sun is brighter than either the moon or the planets.
Countries aren't more numerous than customs. (figuratively: so many men, so many minds)
Wouldn't a car be better than a bicycle?

7.2.en: Simple Forms of the Copula and Initial Mutations
